title: 113_hr1783
content: The "School Food Modernization Act" may be cited as the short title of this Act. Definitions are provided in Section 2. The "School Food Modernization Act" defines key terms such as durable equipment, eligible entity, infrastructure, and local educational agency. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 defines terms like school lunch program, tribal organization, and Secretary of Agriculture. Loan guarantee available for schools to improve infrastructure and equipment for healthy meal programs. The Secretary of Agriculture can issue loan guarantees to eligible entities for infrastructure or equipment financing to support healthy school meal programs. Selection is competitive, with preferences given to entities showing substantial need for infrastructure improvements or durable equipment. The Secretary oversees infrastructure and equipment projects funded by loan guarantees, limiting guarantees to 90% of the loan amount and utilizing the Commodity Credit Corporation for funding. The Equipment Grant Program is outlined in Section 4. Section 7 of the Child Nutrition Act of 1966 is amended to include a new subsection (j) for Equipment Grants. Starting from fiscal year 2015, grants will be provided to eligible entities to purchase equipment for healthier meals and improved food safety. Priority will be given to entities serving a high percentage of students eligible for free or reduced-price meals. The Equipment Grants program under the Child Nutrition Act of 1966 defines terms like durable equipment, eligible entity, and infrastructure for the purpose of providing grants to entities like local educational agencies and tribal organizations for purchasing equipment to improve food safety and meal quality. SEC. 5. TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR SCHOOL FOOD SERVICE PERSONNEL. The Secretary will award grants to eligible third-party training institutions to provide support for school foodservice personnel to meet updated nutrition standards. Specific criteria will be established for these institutions to receive grants, including demonstrated capacity and prior successful experience in training programs. The Secretary will award grants to eligible third-party training institutions with prior successful experience in providing training and technical assistance programming on child and school nutrition topics. The institutions must also have the ability to deliver cost-efficient training to school foodservice personnel in close proximity to schools or worksites. The Secretary will assist institutions in publicizing training materials and tools. The Federal share of costs for training shall not exceed 90%, with matching support required from third-party institutions. Oversight procedures will be established by the Secretary. The Secretary will provide training and technical assistance funded through grants, ensuring it aligns with the goals of the Act. The Secretary will submit annual progress reports to Congress on implementing the Act. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal year 2014 and beyond to support the Act.
